finding: Multiple functional variants associated with the rs965513 SNP contributed to the risk of thyroid cancer, indicating the importance of this SNP in understanding thyroid malignancies.
title: SNPector: SNP inspecting tool to detect disease existence and drug response in direct naked sequencing depends on mutation index

finding: The variant R95G (rs121909332) was identified as pathogenic and was associated with Inclusion Body Myopathy with Early-Onset Paget Disease and Frontotemporal Dementia 1. It fell under the pathogenic category based on clinical significance, having evidence for disease association.
title: In-silico Study of the Uncertainly Significant VCP Variants reveal major Structural, Functional fluctuations leading to potential Disease-Based Associations

finding: The variant R191Q (rs121909334) was also classified as pathogenic, being strongly associated with various conditions including Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis and Inclusion Body Myopathy with Early-Onset Paget Disease. It was reported to have a significant impact on protein function.
title: In-silico Study of the Uncertainly Significant VCP Variants reveal major Structural, Functional fluctuations leading to potential Disease-Based Associations

finding: The variant rs4498662 was identified as the lead i-rQTL variant affecting CARD9-208, contributing to decreased expression of the isoform relating to ankylosing spondylitis and inflammatory bowel disease.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The variant rs10781499, in strong LD with rs4498662, influenced the ratio of CARD9 isoforms, specifically decreasing CARD9-208, which lacks the functional CARD domain necessary for mediating interactions.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The rs10758593 was linked to the CDC37L1-DT locus associated with fasting glucose and type 1 diabetes (T1D), and was confirmed as the lead candidate causal variant with strong eQTL evidence in fetal-like iPSC-PPCs.
title: eQTL mapping in fetal-like pancreatic progenitor cells reveals early developmental insights into diabetes risk

finding: For rs7030868, the findings indicated that this SNP was associated with therapy resistance in melanoma, where alterations in WNT5A signaling were suggested to play a role in treatment outcomes.
title: RNF43 inhibits WNT5A driven signaling and suppresses melanoma invasion

finding: This SNP variant was associated with mean platelet volume, indicating a significant role in regulating platelet function related to thrombosis.
title: LRRC8 complexes are adenosine nucleotide release channels regulating platelet activation and arterial thrombosis

finding: The SNP rs10120474 was associated with the TYRO3 gene, which has emerged as a therapeutic target in cancer. The findings indicated that variations in this SNP may influence the role of TYRO3 in oncogenic signaling pathways, thereby implicating it in cancer progression and therapeutic responses.
title: Novel substrate prediction for the TAM family of RTKs using phosphoproteomics and structure-based modeling

finding: The intronic variant rs822339 in PD-L1 was associated with overall survival in multiple cancer types, including lung adenocarcinoma and kidney chromophobe cancer, which confirmed associations related to immune evasion.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: This variant was associated with lower odds of being an immunotherapy responder despite increased expression of PSMD11, marking it as a potential negative biomarker in treatment contexts.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: The SNP rs10738607 was associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) risk and was located under strong selection around the 9p21 locus. This locus was noted for its pronounced constraint, exhibiting a Z-score of 4.48. Importantly, rs10738607 was established as a well-replicated CAD marker and linked to the cell cycle suppressor gene CDKN2B, with its risk allele predicted to disrupt a binding site for the transcriptional activator STAT5A, which is known to negatively regulate cell proliferation.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The SNP rs2808772 located near the COL27A1 gene had an initial P value of 1.49 × 10^-8, and in the joint meta-analysis, it reached a P value of 2.56 × 10^-11. Although direct studies on LOC105376225 were lacking, the proximity to COL27A1, which is involved in cartilage calcification and previously suggested associations with osteoarthritis, supported the significant findings.
title: A genome-wide association study identifies that the GDF5 and COL27A1 genes are associated with knee pain in UK Biobank (N = 171, 516)

finding: The SNP rs10217259 displayed increased transcriptional activity linked to psoriasis by enhancing JUN binding to the KLF4 promoter, indicating a mechanism that might dysregulate epidermal differentiation.
title: Disease-Linked Regulatory DNA Variants and Homeostatic Transcription Factors in Epidermis

finding: The SNP rs10962612 was associated with sun sensitivity, tagging a Neanderthal haplotype found at approximately 70% frequency in Europeans. It was located near the gene BNC2, which significantly influences skin pigmentation levels and was linked to increased incidence of childhood sunburn and poor tanning in the UK Biobank.
title: Quantifying the contribution of Neanderthal introgression to the heritability of complex traits

finding: The SNP rs62543578 was reported in a region that tagged introgressed haplotypes related to sun sensitivity and was implicated in increasing the incidence of childhood sunburn and poor tanning in the UK Biobank. It was also located near the gene BNC2, associated with skin pigmentation.
title: Quantifying the contribution of Neanderthal introgression to the heritability of complex traits

finding: The SNP rs495828 in the ABO locus was found to be associated with traits across 7 distinct trait domains. This suggests that rs495828 had a widespread influence on multiple traits beyond the initial trait domain, indicating a significant pleiotropic effect, which was a central focus of the analysis conducted using the PolarMorphism method.
title: PolarMorphism enables discovery of shared genetic variants across multiple traits from GWAS summary statistics

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with glycine, with a significant finding (P = 3.3 × 10^-10) from a sample of 5447 subjects. It is an intronic variant in the glycine decarboxylase (GLDC) gene, which plays a central role in glycine metabolism and may relate to metabolic and neurological disorders.
title: Meta-Analysis of Urinary Metabolite GWAS Studies Identifies Three Novel Genome-Wide Significant Loci

finding: The SNP rs657152 at locus 9q34.2 was also identified as significant at the genome-wide level in the same GWAS study. This locus indicated a genetic susceptibility that impacts the outcomes of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 genome sequence variations relate to morbidity and mortality in Coronavirus Disease-19

finding: rs35568725, identified as coding for the Ser251Pro variant in the PLIN2 gene, was also found to be significantly associated with NASH. An allelic odds ratio of 2.74 was observed, signifying that carriers of this SNP were significantly more likely to have NASH. The study concluded that this SNP could serve as an independent risk factor for NASH, paralleling findings from the analysis of rs3556875.
title: A single nucleotide polymorphism of PLIN2 is associated with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and causes phenotypic changes in hepatocyte lipid droplets

finding: The SNP rs1049430, located in the 3'-UTR of the SH3GL2 gene, was found to regulate the expression of this gene. This regulation was linked to clinical and prognostic implications in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, highlighting the SNP's role in cancer biology.
title: scReQTL: an approach to correlate SNVs to gene expression from individual scRNA-seq datasets

finding: The SNP rs500102 was identified as a putative causal variant for schizophrenia. It overlapped with a loop-connected DMR in Layer 4-5 excitatory neurons, where it was linked to the regulation of RORB gene expression. The study found that this SNP had a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 0.27, indicating its significance. Additionally, rs500102 was also recognized as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the RORB gene in brain tissue according to GTEx studies. The research highlighted the importance of chromatin conformational changes in mediating the effects of GWAS-associated variants, exemplifying this through the functional relationship between rs500102 and the RORB promoter.
title: Epigenomic and chromosomal architectural reconfiguration in developing human frontal cortex and hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs657152 at locus 9q34.2 was investigated in relation to the ABO blood-group system and demonstrated a significant association with COVID-19 susceptibility, marking it as an essential genetic factor in exploring receptor interactions.
title: The discovery of a recombinant SARS2-like CoV strain provides insights into SARS and COVID-19 pandemics

finding: The finding related to rs7875199 was linked to the gene MTAP, which lost a target site for a highly expressed microRNA in non-African populations. This target site was ancestral and conserved in other primates. The loss of this target site in non-African populations correlated with elevated MTAP expression, potentially due to relaxed selective pressures in those populations. This was postulated to contribute to the observed higher melanoma incidence in these populations, particularly in relation to latitude.
title: The impact of population variation in the analysis of microRNA target sites

finding: Similar to rs7875199, the finding for rs7868374 indicated a loss of a target site for a highly expressed microRNA in non-African populations at the MTAP gene. This target site loss was linked to an increase in MTAP expression in these populations, possibly due to reduced evolutionary pressures compared to African populations. The relationship between the target allele frequency and latitude further suggested that populations from higher latitudes exhibited lower frequencies of the target allele, which could relate to an increased risk of skin cancer.
title: The impact of population variation in the analysis of microRNA target sites

finding: The SNP rs118017926 was identified as a credible causal SNP and located in the ZNF462 gene, which encodes a zinc-finger transcription factor important for embryonic neurodevelopment.
title: Genome-wide association study of cerebellar volume

finding: The SNP rs72754248 was deemed a credible causal SNP, showing strong association with cerebellar volume and was located in the PAPPA gene, which regulates IGF1 availability by cleaving insulin-like growth factor binding proteins.
title: Genome-wide association study of cerebellar volume

finding: The study revealed the genetic variant rs1563 in maize, which was part of a comprehensive genome-scale metabolic reconstruction of maize metabolism. It was associated with significant metabolic reprogramming under nitrogen-deficient conditions, contributing to insights regarding nutrient uptake, particularly under stress conditions.
title: Dissecting the Metabolic Reprogramming of Maize Root under Nitrogen Limiting Stress Condition

finding: Similar to rs6120849, the dark allele at rs7870409 near RALGPS1 also showed evidence of decreased frequency more significant than ancestry factors, suggesting selective pressures at play.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The RABGAP1 locus with SNP rs644490 exhibited elevated selection signals particularly in Early Farmer and Steppe ancestry populations.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: At the TYRP1 locus, rs1325132 was associated with selection evidence, confirming its significance in skin pigmentation in the hunter-gatherer lineage.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The rs1172922 SNP was connected to the CTCF binding site for the SYK gene, which has implications in inflammatory responses linked to AD.
title: A Network-based Deep Learning Framework Catalyzes GWAS and Multi-Omics Findings to Biology and Drug Repurposing for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was identified with high confidence by the fine-mapping methods FINEMAP, SuSiE-inf, and FINEMAP-inf. It replicated previous findings where a luciferase assay provided orthogonal evidence for its causality related to the trait Plt.
title: Improving fine-mapping by modeling infinitesimal effects

finding: Similar to rs12005199, this SNP was consistently detected with high confidence by FINEMAP, SuSiE-inf, and FINEMAP-inf, also replicating earlier findings that suggested its causality for trait Plt based on luciferase assays.
title: Improving fine-mapping by modeling infinitesimal effects

finding: The SNP rs7040890 was linked to the contribution of prostate cancer stem-like cells to the development of castration-resistant prostate cancer. This finding suggested that the presence of this SNP could have implications for the aggressiveness of PCa and its response to therapies.
title: Identification of a Micropeptide Linked to Cancer Stem Cell Regulation and Chemoresistance

finding: The SNP rs10809485 located on chromosome 9p23 was significantly associated with Lifetime Anxiety Disorder, showing a p-value of 1.6×10−12. It was found to be in an intergenic region and its association contributes to understanding the genetic basis of anxiety disorders.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: The SNP rs1187280 in an intron of the gene Neurotrophic Receptor Tyrosine Kinase 2 (NTRK2) was found to be significantly associated with anxiety, with a p-value of 5.2×10−8, supporting its role in the genetic architecture of anxiety disorders.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: SNP rs10959883 at the 9q21.33 locus was confirmed to replicate in analyses of Neuroticism and Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), showing significant association with Lifetime Anxiety Disorder. Its replication reinforces the connection between these phenotypes.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: SNP rs10959577 was associated with Lifetime Anxiety Disorder in a meta-analysis, showing significance nearly identical to the 9p23 region, and demonstrates genetic overlap between different anxiety measures.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: The SNP rs11515172 was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) in an analysis of 126,522 genotyped individuals of European ancestry from the UK Biobank. It showed a significant association with MDD overall, remaining significant upon logistic regression (p = 4.69 x 10^-8, OR = 0.96). This locus, located on Chromosome 9 at 11Mb, had been previously associated with depression and neuroticism in multiple studies that also involved UK Biobank data. It was noted that this locus is intergenic and is not currently linked to any known biological feature of interest.
title: Genome-wide gene-environment analyses of major depressive disorder and reported lifetime traumatic experiences in UK Biobank

finding: Evidence of selection was noted at rs2153271 in the BNC2 gene, which is associated with freckling. The analysis indicated moderate selection but did not provide precise estimates for the selection coefficient.
title: An approximate full-likelihood method for inferring selection and allele frequency trajectories from DNA sequence data

finding: The SNP rs6478109 was associated with childhood SSNS in the Japanese cohort and replicated in the meta-analysis, showing protective effects consistent across populations.
title: Common risk variants in AHI1 are associated with childhood steroid-sensitive nephrotic syndrome

finding: Cartus et al. (2019) reported on benchmarking the retrieval of biomass in boreal forests using multi-temporal P-band SAR backscatter combined with C- and L-band observations, showcasing advancements in biomass estimation methods.
title: Using hypertemporal Sentinel-1 data to predict forest growing stock volume

finding: The study identified rs11538707 (CREB3 R119G) as a rare variant that conferred a 40% reduction in the risk of developing ALS and was associated with slower disease progression, extending disease duration by approximately 12 months. This finding was derived from integration of genetic and transcriptomic analyses in ALS patients.
title: CREB3 gain of function variants protect against ALS

finding: The SNP rs3011285 was associated with the modulation of Glutathione Reductase (GSR), a key enzyme implicated in cell death within GSR-dependent lung cancers. The finding highlighted the role of zinc in regulating GSR activity, which was linked to cancer genetic dependencies sensitive to zinc-induced cytotoxicity.
title: A comprehensive landscape of the zinc-regulated human proteome

finding: The intronic variant rs8176671 was strongly linked to CDH5 protein levels, with a MAF of 0.19 and a P-value of 8.83 × 10^-40.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The deletion variant rs8176643 exhibited a notable association with the levels of SELE, recorded on 1q24.2 with a MAF of 0.18 and a P-value of 7.98 × 10^-36.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The variant rs12216891 correlated with the CTRC protein levels, manifesting a MAF of 0.19 and a significant P-value of 8.39 × 10^-30.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The intronic variant rs507666 was the lead variant with the most associations overall, specifically regarding blood cell traits.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The SNP rs2153271 demonstrated an association with DNAm sites influencing pigmentation, marking a significant discovery in the context of skin cancer risk.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The rs2737273 SNP was associated with a decrease in BMD and increased TPM2 isoforms containing exon 6. Conversely, the alternative allele was associated with higher BMD alongside increased isoforms containing exon 7. This shows a direct impact of the SNP on the splicing events for TPM2, illustrating the complex interactions of the genetic effects on bone mineral density.
title: Long-read proteogenomics to connect disease-associated sQTLs to the protein isoform effectors of disease

finding: The rs3215700 SNP was linked to higher levels of TPM2 isoforms containing exon 6, which are associated with lower bone mineral density (BMD). This SNP plays a role in regulating alternative splicing of TPM2 and demonstrates how genetic variants can influence splicing and ultimately affect phenotype outcomes such as BMD.
title: Long-read proteogenomics to connect disease-associated sQTLs to the protein isoform effectors of disease

finding: The SNP rs35199210, which resulted in an Asp238Glu amino acid change, segregated with Alzheimer disease (AD) in a family containing six affected individuals. The rarity of the allele (frequency < 0.01) and its high CADD score (16.2) indicated that it may be a damaging variant, and in silico predictions classified it as highly deleterious.
title: Linkage Analysis in Caribbean Hispanic Families with Puerto Rican Ancestry Idenitfies an Alzheimer Disease Locus on chromosome 9

finding: The SNP rs41276043, leading to a Phe1096Leu change, was also identified as a high priority variant within the gene UNC13B and was observed to segregate with Alzheimer's disease in multiple families. This SNP had a CADD score exceeding 22, further substantiating its classification as potentially damaging and highly deleterious based on in silico evaluation.
title: Linkage Analysis in Caribbean Hispanic Families with Puerto Rican Ancestry Idenitfies an Alzheimer Disease Locus on chromosome 9

finding: The V727M mutation, associated with rs121908627, was found to be largely predicted as 'pathogenic' by in silico platforms. However, it exhibited moderate hyposialylation when compared to controls. This suggests that while V727M is prevalent and contributes to the genetic profile of GNE myopathy, its effect on the pathology may be less severe than indicated due to its occurrence in a compound heterozygous state.
title: Efficient GNE myopathy disease modeling with mutation specific phenotypes in human pluripotent stem cells by base editors

finding: The SNP rs7864322 was found to be associated with hypothyroidism. This trans-eQTL was discovered in thyroid tissue and was reported to control the expression of the nearby PTCSC2 lncRNA and the FOXE1 gene, which are involved in thyroid regulation and development respectively. Additionally, the distant target genes linked to this SNP were enriched in the 'thyroid hormone signaling' pathway.
title: Reverse regression increases power for detecting trans-eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs4297160 was also associated with hypothyroidism. Identified in thyroid tissue, it was shown to regulate the expression of the PTCSC2 lncRNA and FOXE1 gene. Notably, the DIO1 gene on chromosome 1 targeted by rs4297160 is crucial for the production of T3 hormone, highlighting the potential underlying mechanism for thyroid action effectively linking this SNP to thyroid dysfunction.
title: Reverse regression increases power for detecting trans-eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs10983975 was linked to hypothyroidism. This trans-eQTL, discovered in thyroid tissue, controlled the expression of the PTCSC2 lncRNA and FOXE1 gene, both significant in thyroid function. Similar to the other two SNPs, the distant target genes showed an enrichment in the 'thyroid hormone signaling' pathway, suggesting a role in thyroid-related disease mechanisms.
title: Reverse regression increases power for detecting trans-eQTLs

finding: This variant resided in a region of active enhancer-associated chromatin downstream of GFI1B, indicating its importance in HSC functioning and MPN predisposition.
title: Genetic predisposition to myeloproliferative neoplasms implicates hematopoietic stem cell biology

finding: A 684-bp deletion in an intergenic region of chromosome 9 (chr9:101,457,417-101,458,101) was found to be in almost perfect linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs2183745 at chr9:101,456,893, which was strongly associated with alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level (P=2×10−133). This indicated a potential functional contribution of the SV to the associated phenotype.
title: Structural variation across 138,134 samples in the TOPMed consortium

finding: The variant rs4543592 was also noted as a pleiotropic variant for the association between lifetime smoking and WHR<sub>adjBMI</sub>, indicating a potential genetic influence on abdominal fat distribution related to smoking behavior.
title: Estimating the causal relationship between smoking and abdominal adiposity using Mendelian randomization

finding: The SNP rs1933683, associated with an increased risk for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), exhibited a significantly higher incidence in patients with both esophageal atresia (EA) and IHPS, with an odds ratio of 3.29 (p=0.009). This was notably different from the population frequency, indicating a strong genetic component linking this SNP to the development of IHPS in EA patients.
title: Models for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis development in patients with esophageal atresia

finding: The SNP rs7040890 was associated with the development of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), as reported in the study by Ojo et al. This research indicated that prostate cancer stem-like cells, potentially influenced by this SNP, contributed to the progression of CRPC. The identification of rs7040890 highlighted its significance as a genetic marker related to the pathology of castration resistance in prostate cancer.
title: The soluble guanylyl cyclase pathway is inhibited to evade androgen deprivation-induced senescence and enable progression to castration resistance

finding: This SNP is located within intron 3 of the C9orf72 gene and contributed to the pathways relevant to ALS, showing a significant association with the disease risk.
title: Genetic analysis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis identifies contributing pathways and cell types

finding: This variant replaced rs12973192 through the clumping procedure and was assessed for its role in ALS risk, indicating a significant association with the disease.
title: Genetic analysis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis identifies contributing pathways and cell types

finding: This SNP was associated with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome in Caucasian patients with PCOS or hirsutism as referral diagnosis, highlighting its relevance in the genetic basis of PCOS.
title: Unique genetic features of the naked mole-rat’s THADA gene

finding: The SNP rs11536889 was associated with specific miR-1236 binding to the G allele over the C allele in the 3'-UTR of the Toll-like receptor 4. This provided evidence that miR-1236 preferentially targeted the variant allele, highlighting its role in gene regulation.
title: An alternative miRISC targeting a coding mutation site in FOXL2 links to granulosa cell tumor

finding: The SNP rs129891 was associated with an increased likelihood of being a current smoker, particularly among participants who carried more copies of the minor allele 'A' (p=0.045). Additionally, those carrying this allele exhibited significantly lower fractional anisotropy (FA) measures across three regions of the corpus callosum (GCC: p=1.75×10^-2; BCC: p=4.97×10^-2; SCC: p=3.15×10^-2), indicating a risk for both reduced white matter integrity and increased nicotine addiction. In a mediation model, the FA measures in these regions acted as significant mediators linking genetic effects to smoking status.
title: White matter integrity and nicotine dependence in smokers: evaluating vertical and horizontal pleiotropy

finding: The SNP rs1461780285 was significantly associated with lactose and galactose degradation, indicated by a discovery p-value of 2.10 × 10^-12 and a replication p-value of 1.09 × 10^-10. It was located in the ABO blood group and was in strong linkage disequilibrium with other SNPs associated with metabolite levels.
title: Mendelian randomization analyses support causal relationships between blood metabolites and the gut microbiome

finding: The SNP rs182096718, which results in the D130A substitution in ANP32B, was found to be more frequent in the Hispanic/Latino cohort, where 1,209 heterozygous and 25 homozygous carriers were identified. This variant exhibited a dominant negative effect over wildtype ANP32B and impaired FluPol activity, leading to compromised influenza virus replication, suggesting a potential genetic protection against the virus.
title: A rare variant in ANP32B impairs influenza virus replication in human cells

finding: The SNP rs10120514 was positively associated with triple receptor negative breast cancer (TNBC) in African-American women. This association highlighted the significance of obesity, biological factors, and socioeconomic determinants in contributing to racial disparities in health outcomes, particularly the poor survival prognosis linked with low SPCA2 expression in TNBC.
title: Epigenetic Modulation of SPCA2 Reverses Epithelial to Mesenchymal Transition in Breast Cancer Cells

finding: The SNP rs1575972 was reported to be significantly associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) with a P-value of 4.7×10−13. An NRS located 158 kb upstream of DMRTA1 was noted to be in high linkage disequilibrium (r² > 0.8) with rs1575972 and flanked three other SNPs significantly associated with diabetes (P = 2.4×10−11 to 1.8×10−11), suggesting the NRS's potential contribution to T2D susceptibility.
title: Graph pangenome reveals functional, evolutionary, and phenotypic significance of human nonreference sequences

finding: The SNP rs7859844 was identified as one of three genome-wide significant associations for recurrent miscarriage. It had a MAF of 6.4% and a meta-analysis P-value of 1.3×10^-8, with interactions suggested with genes like TLE1 in fetal thymus, which are proposed to control extravillous trophoblast motility.
title: The genetic architecture of sporadic and recurrent miscarriage

finding: The SNP rs10991386 was confirmed as part of the subset of enhancers that displayed differential activity due to transcription factor binding site disruptions in the analysis of Alzheimer's disease-related genetic variations. Although specific details about its enhancer activity were less emphasized compared to rs6498140, it was noted among the two SNPs showing conclusive effects on enhancer functionality as part of the study.
title: An in vivo massively parallel platform for deciphering tissue-specific regulatory function

finding: This SNP was identified as an astrocyte-specific expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) regulating NDUFA8, a gene linked to both Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. Although it had a known immune-related phenotypic association, it lacked prior reports of associations with brain-related phenotypes.
title: Minimum entropy framework identifies a novel class of genomic functional elements and reveals regulatory mechanisms at human disease loci

finding: The CARD9 G111R mutation (rs769183409) showed some presence in the Genebass database although it was linked to a lower activity level compared to G111E, highlighting its intermediate role in activation potential.
title: Chimeric and mutant CARD9 constructs enable analyses of conserved and diverged autoinhibition mechanisms in the CARD-CC protein family

finding: This variant was linked to factors such as coagulation factor VIII and von Willebrand factor, establishing its relevance in predicting respiratory failure risk in COVID-19 patients.
title: Genetic architecture of host proteins interacting with SARS-CoV-2

finding: rs534035399 was identified at LINC01508 and associated with the strength of 1-day periodicity in circadian rhythm, showing a p-value of 1.8×10^-9.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: rs554696049 was at LINC01501 and associated with the strength of 1-day periodicity, with a p-value of 4.8×10^-8.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: The SNP rs6478109 located in the TNFSF15 gene was associated with an increased susceptibility to Crohn's disease based on a meta-analysis conducted by Zhou et al. (2020). This finding was significant as it highlighted the genetic factor influencing Crohn's disease, whereas no similar association was identified for ulcerative colitis.
title: Speos: An ensemble graph representation learning framework to predict core genes for complex diseases

finding: The study found that the SNP rs10781499 within the CARD9 gene was associated with impaired microbial production of AhR ligands in patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). This SNP was relevant because it correlated with the ability of the microbiota to produce necessary metabolites that aid in immune response and recovery from colitis, indicating a genetic influence on microbiota functionality that could impact IBD susceptibility.
title: Dissecting the respective roles of microbiota and host genetics in the susceptibility of Card9-/- mice to colitis

finding: The SNP rs1015250 had a high heterozygosity value of 0.5030, showcasing its prominence and potential as a genetic marker.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: This SNP showed a moderate frequency and a higher impact value, contributing positively to the forensic genetic landscape.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: The study found a significant association between the protein truncating variant rs146597587 in the IL33 gene and asthma. Specifically, the p-value for the association was recorded as 7.1×10−7 when cases were ascertained through hospital records, compared to a much stronger p-value of 2.4×10−14 for cases identified through questionnaire responses. This finding highlighted the importance of the method used for case ascertainment in GWAS.
title: Assessing digital phenotyping to enhance genetic studies of human diseases

finding: The rs10812921 SNP was related to intracranial volume (ICV) variability, explaining 0.07% of the variance with a p-value of 5.5×10^-8. Results were consistent even in the healthy control subgroup analyzed.
title: Genetic control of variability in subcortical and intracranial volumes

finding: The locus chr9:28995582:C:A was associated with ICV variability, consistent with the findings related to SNP rs10812921.
title: Genetic control of variability in subcortical and intracranial volumes

finding: The non-coding transcript exon variant rs574843917 in GPR21 was found to be significantly associated with height. This discovery points to the value of using WGS insights rather than relying solely on imputed SNP data.
title: Joint modelling of whole genome sequence data for human height via approximate message passing

finding: There was evidence that SNP rs10453229 was linked to the eGene LPAR1 via a 400 Kb chromatin loop and was associated with the chondrocyte response to matrix damage and OA. This finding was supported by increased gene expression as a response to FN-f treatment.
title: Response eQTLs, chromatin accessibility, and 3D chromatin structure in chondrocytes provide mechanistic insight into osteoarthritis risk

finding: SNP rs1321917 was associated with increased expression of PAPPA in chondrocytes. This locus was colocalized with the Total Hip Replacement GWAS signal in both conditions, supporting its link to OA risk.
title: Response eQTLs, chromatin accessibility, and 3D chromatin structure in chondrocytes provide mechanistic insight into osteoarthritis risk

finding: SNP rs1885244 showed an effect on PAPPA expression in response to both PBS and FN-f treatments. Its connections to the associated OA signals enriched its relevance.
title: Response eQTLs, chromatin accessibility, and 3D chromatin structure in chondrocytes provide mechanistic insight into osteoarthritis risk

finding: This SNP was associated with anxiety-related disorders in the phenome-wide association study (PheWAS), showcasing significant associations with a p-value of 8.74×10⁻⁶.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: rs10985817 was tagged as a locus for schizophrenia and achieved a PIP ≥ 0.1. It was located within an OCR specifically present in dentate gyrus excitatory neurons, thus linking it to a potential role in schizophrenia.
title: Leveraging mouse chromatin data for heritability enrichment informs common disease architecture and reveals cortical layer contributions to schizophrenia

finding: Associated with the GABBR2 locus along with rs10985817, it also achieved a PIP ≥ 0.1 and fell within an OCR in dentate gyrus excitatory neurons, supporting hypotheses regarding its functionality in neuronal contexts.
title: Leveraging mouse chromatin data for heritability enrichment informs common disease architecture and reveals cortical layer contributions to schizophrenia

finding: The rs10817103 SNP, located in the LPAR1 gene, was found to be significantly associated with anxiety in a cohort of 2479 patients. Individuals carrying the T allele had a 40% lower risk of developing anxiety compared to those with the CC genotype, with an odds ratio of 0.61. This SNP was noted to decrease expression of the LPA1 receptor and was located in an enhancer region active in neurons, linking genetic factors to LPA16:0-LPA1 signaling and anxiety phenotypes.
title: Platelet-derived LPA16:0 inhibits adult neurogenesis and stress resilience in anxiety disorder

finding: The SNP rs7030860 was identified as a significant association with the signaling pathways of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) and G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). This finding related to enhanced cellular signaling mechanisms that were linked to diverse physiological roles in synaptic plasticity, specifically in the context of hippocampal responses to brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF). The context indicated that variations in this SNP could modulate the activity of TrkB and mGluR5, affecting Ca<sup>2+</sup> signaling and MAP kinase activation, which were crucial for understanding crosstalk between RTK and GPCR superfamilies.
title: Synaptic plasticity via receptor tyrosine kinase/G protein-coupled receptor crosstalk

finding: The VLDLR locus contained rs7030781, which exhibited significant association (meta-P-value = 3.78 × 10-13) with the cytokine network, supporting its links to immune response and metabolic traits.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of a cytokine network reveals variants with widespread immune, haematological and cardiometabolic pleiotropy

finding: The ABO locus featured rs550057 with a meta-P-value of 2.75 × 10-8. This SNP was implicated in both ABO blood type determination and in the regulation of various inflammatory proteins and lipid traits.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of a cytokine network reveals variants with widespread immune, haematological and cardiometabolic pleiotropy

finding: The CDKN2B-AS1 rs1333049 G/C variant was involved in the risk assessment for coronary heart disease, establishing its relevance in cardiovascular disorders.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Cardiac Arrest by Integrated Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The CDKN2B-AS1 variant rs4977574 was linked to hypertension, further highlighting its role in cardiovascular diseases.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Cardiac Arrest by Integrated Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The CDKN2B-AS rs2383207 polymorphism was discussed in relation to susceptibility to atherosclerosis, underscoring its importance in cardiovascular diseases.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Cardiac Arrest by Integrated Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: Lead eQTL rs10983265 was associated with PAPPA expression and indicated the same direction of effect in both PBS and FN-f, underlining its significance.
title: Response eQTLs, chromatin accessibility, and 3D chromatin structure in chondrocytes provide mechanistic insight into osteoarthritis risk

finding: Associated with immature reticulocyte fraction, this SNP exhibited a strong maternal effect (maternal p-value = 2 × 10^-8) and was linked to the expression of RCL1 in blood, reinforcing its potential PofO status.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: The mutations Y89H and Y89D, linked to Classical Galactosemia, were shown to significantly affect the predicted tyrosine-based motif in GALAC1 (P07902), with both mutations resulting in protein stability reductions exceeding 6 kcal/mol.
title: MotSASi: Functional Short Linear Motifs (SLiMs) prediction based on genomic single nucleotide variants and structural data

finding: Part of the FDA5 PRS, rs9409226 is upstream of genes linked to obesity-related traits, including FBXW2 (associated with BMI-adjusted hip circumference) and PHF19 (associated with birth weight). It contributed positively to predictive performance on growth metrics.
title: Polygenic risk score based on weight gain trajectories is predictive of childhood obesity

finding: The rs579459 polymorphism was associated with the AGT activity, which is crucial for determining the A1 blood group. The study found that patients with venous thrombosis exhibited decreased GT activities compared to controls, and AGT activity explained approximately 80% of the variance within A blood group individuals.
title: ABO blood group, glycosyltransferase activity and risk of Venous Thrombosis

finding: The rs8176743 polymorphism was associated with the BGT activity related to the B blood group. Lower BGT activity was observed in cases versus controls, supporting the hypothesis that BGT activity plays a role in the modified risk of venous thrombosis.
title: ABO blood group, glycosyltransferase activity and risk of Venous Thrombosis

finding: The rs1053878 SNP was linked to the A2 blood group classification, characterized by reduced AGT activity. This polymorphism contributed to the study's findings that patients exhibited lower GT activities compared to matched controls.
title: ABO blood group, glycosyltransferase activity and risk of Venous Thrombosis

finding: The rs8176719 SNP, which results in an inactive enzyme leading to the O blood type, was noted in the study. It highlighted differences in AGT activity among blood groups, as individuals expressing this allele only exhibited the H antigen with no GT activity.
title: ABO blood group, glycosyltransferase activity and risk of Venous Thrombosis

finding: The missense variant rs765246726 (p.Cys2107Arg) in ABCA1 was found to be associated with a mean reduction in HDL-C of 0.64 mmol/l, contributing to significant variations in cholesterol metabolism.
title: Exome sequencing identifies high-impact trait-associated alleles enriched in Finns

finding: The predicted damaging missense variant rs77273740 (p.Arg65Trp) in DBH was identified as 23.8 times more frequent in the Finnish population compared to Northern Europeans and was associated with a mean decrease of 1 mmHg in diastolic blood pressure, suggesting its link to cardiovascular health.
title: Exome sequencing identifies high-impact trait-associated alleles enriched in Finns

finding: The rs12722 variant in the COL5A1 gene was associated with pulmonary tuberculosis in a case-control study conducted in Kazakhstan by Zhetkenev et al. in 2021.
title: Comprehensive analysis of next-generation sequencing data in COVID-19 and its secondary complications

finding: The rs382940 SNP within the SLC44A1 gene was associated with a faster progression to Hoehn and Yahr stage 3 (HY3) (HR 2.04 [1.58, 2.62], P-value = 3.46E-8), marking a significant breakthrough in understanding the disease's progression.
title: Genome-wide association study of Parkinson’s disease progression biomarkers in 12 longitudinal patients’ cohorts

finding: The variant rs111245230, linked to SVEP1 levels, was associated with coronary heart disease (CHD), blood pressure, and type-2 diabetes (T2D). This variant indicated that higher levels of SVEP1 correlated with increased risk of these conditions.
title: Human serum proteome profoundly overlaps with genetic signatures of disease

finding: The SNP rs7040882 was involved in the study of TRPM8 ion channels, where it was found to correlate with the mechanism through which menthol affected human bronchial epithelium. Specifically, the presence of this SNP facilitated increased calcium influx and mitochondrial reactive oxygen species indicative of oxidative stress. This mechanism was significant in relation to respiratory diseases, as TRPM8 receptor activity was linked to both inflammatory responses and oxidative stress resulting from menthol exposure.
title: Menthol in Electronic Cigarettes: A Contributor to Respiratory Disease?

finding: The rs4742170 variant, derived from the Neanderthal lineage, was associated with the IL33 gene and implicated in asthma and childhood wheezing. This variant's T allele was identified as the disease risk allele, disrupting glucocorticoid receptor binding to a putative IL33 enhancer, leading to increased IL33 enhancer activity and elevated levels of IL-33, which are known to cause asthma phenotypes.
title: A Neanderthal Origin of Genetic Variants Associated with Asthma

finding: The research discovered a preferential binding of the ATXN10 gRNA to the alternative C allele of the heterozygous SNP rs7861875 in the HEK293 cell line. The T allele was associated with a higher mismatch count with the gRNA, resulting in reduced binding efficiency. Analysis indicated that 95% of the SMRT-OTS reads corresponded to the C allele, reflecting a significant bias in gRNA binding that could impact off-target editing. Additionally, it was noted that the C allele frequency in the population was 0.20, suggesting that approximately 20% of individuals may experience altered gRNA interactions at this locus.
title: Amplification-free long read sequencing reveals unforeseen CRISPR-Cas9 off-target activity

finding: Similar to rs9469775, rs4837613 was replicated in the ALM analysis of the elderly group, indicating it contributes to the genetic variability affecting muscle mass.
title: Genome-wide associations reveal human-mouse genetic convergence and modifiers of myogenesis, CPNE1 and STC2

finding: The study evaluated the impact of the coding SNP rs10757668 in the exon 2 splice acceptor of the patient line, which allowed for the determination of the proportion of transcripts derived from wild-type (WT) and mutant alleles. Results indicated that over 90% of exon 1A-containing transcripts in unedited patient lines originated from the mutant allele. This imbalance was corrected following repeat expansion excision, suggesting that the excess of exon 1A activity in the disease state was primarily due to the mutant allele. This finding contributed to understanding the transcriptional upregulation associated with the C9orf72 mutation, implicating it as a biological driver in the pathology of Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).
title: Two therapeutic CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing approaches revert FTD/ALS cellular pathology caused by a C9orf72 repeat expansion mutation in patient derived cells

finding: rs10115898 was associated with Streptococcus mutans, corroborating previous findings with successful replication.
title: Inter-determination of blood metabolite levels and gut microbiome supported by Mendelian randomization

finding: The SNP rs1570247 disrupted the binding of the transcriptional repressor ZNF263 and was correlated with increased expression of the GBA2 gene. This SNP was linked to type 2 diabetes, providing insight into the genetic and regulatory mechanisms contributing to this disease phenotype.
title: Quantitative assessment of association between noncoding variants and transcription factor binding

finding: The SNP rs965513 was associated with an increased risk of thyroid cancer. In the study by He et al. (2015), multiple functional variants within long-range enhancer elements were identified that contributed to this risk, highlighting the regulatory mechanisms influenced by noncoding SNPs in the context of thyroid cancer.
title: Predicting the effects of SNPs on transcription factor binding affinity

finding: The study revealed that the SNP rs10120520 was associated with the oncogenic activation of Nrf2 following the genomic loss of Nrf1α. This relationship demonstrated that Nrf1 functions as a tumor suppressor, and its loss parallels with the activation of β-catenin, promoting processes like epithelial-mesenchymal transition which are essential to tumorigenesis. The expression profiles differed depending on certain regulatory sequences around genes involved, indicating the complex role of rs10120520 in cancer development.
title: Nrf1 is endowed with a dominant tumor-repressing effect onto the Wnt/β-Catenin-dependent and -independent signaling networks in the human liver cancer

finding: The SNP rs1888909, which is associated with asthma, was located within 5kb of the IL-33 gene and was found to overlap with an OCT-1 (POU2F1) binding site. This indicated a regulatory role in IL-33 expression, suggesting that it influenced the expression patterns linked to immune responses and potentially involved in conditions like asthma.
title: Tumor suppressor p53 deficiency increases tumor immunogenicity through promoting IL33-mediated anti-tumor immune responses

finding: The variant rs146597587 was identified as a high-confidence loss of function splice acceptor in the gene IL33, which is implicated in asthma. Its effect size in the UK Biobank was three times greater than the lead colocalized variant rs3939286.
title: Diverse transcriptomic signatures across human tissues identify functional rare genetic variation

finding: The rs958804 SNP in the ASTN2 gene was found to be linked to pain-related phenotypes, indicating its involvement in the genetic underpinnings of opioid dependence and its associated pain management issues among patients post-surgery.
title: Convergence of case-specific epigenetic alterations identify a confluence of genetic vulnerabilities tied to opioid dependence

finding: The rs7858836 SNP, also located within the ASTN2 gene, demonstrated a similar correlation with pain-related phenotypes, further supporting the gene's role in opioid use disorder risk and pain response mechanisms.
title: Convergence of case-specific epigenetic alterations identify a confluence of genetic vulnerabilities tied to opioid dependence

finding: The rare variant rs541856133 was associated with T1D and mapped to a non-coding region upstream of CEL, a gene implicated in MODY8 related to pancreatic exocrine dysfunction.
title: Large-scale genetic association and single cell accessible chromatin mapping defines cell type-specific mechanisms of type 1 diabetes risk

finding: This nonsynonymous variant in the SVEP1 gene was identified as a major contributor to ADP-induced platelet aggregation, indicating its significant role in cardiovascular disease mechanisms. Its association was supported by replication in cohorts, further linking it to increased platelet reactivity.
title: Genome Sequencing Unveils a New Regulatory Landscape of Platelet Reactivity

finding: The rs8187929 mutation on the ALDH1A1 gene was reported to significantly relate to alcohol consumption and drinking behaviors specifically in the Japanese population. Although this SNP predominantly existed in the East Asian population, its minor allele frequency was noted to be lower than that of rs671, at 4.56%. The rs8187929 mutation could disrupt the ALDH1A1-ALDH2 protein-protein interaction and was linked to ethanol metabolism, but its impact was found to be more limited compared to rs671, which was associated with a wider variety of interactions and a higher prevalence in East Asians.
title: The Extent of Edgetic Perturbations in the Human Interactome Caused by Population-Specific Mutations

finding: This variant also correlated with increased odds of MHQ participation, reflecting links to cognitive measures.
title: Genetic predictors of participation in optional components of UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs507666 tagged the A1 subtype, which showed a robust lowering effect on sE-selectin and sICAM-1 levels. This finding suggested a molecular mechanism where the A1 subtype promoted increased glycosyltransferase activity, influencing the shedding or clearance rate of these adhesion molecules from circulation.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies seven novel loci associating with circulating cytokines and cell adhesion molecules in Finns

finding: The lead variant rs2519093 was associated with sE-selectin and sICAM-1 concentrations. Its association remained highly significant even when adjusted for the ABO blood type, indicating its independent influence on these soluble adhesion molecule levels.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies seven novel loci associating with circulating cytokines and cell adhesion molecules in Finns

finding: The SNP rs8176746 showed a robust association with sVCAM-1 concentration. Further analyses indicated that this association was independent of the A1 subtype, suggesting it may be involved in a different mechanism influencing sVCAM-1 levels.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies seven novel loci associating with circulating cytokines and cell adhesion molecules in Finns

finding: The SNP variant rs12337802 was found to be associated with the splicing of the elncRNA RP11-112J3, which in turn correlated with the expression level of its target gene GBA2. An analysis revealed a distribution of splicing indices for RP11-112J3 and expression levels for GBA2 that varied among samples with different alleles of this SNP. This suggests that rs12337802 plays a role in the modulation of elncRNA processing and its subsequent impact on target gene expression.
title: The activity of human enhancers is modulated by the splicing of their associated lncRNAs

finding: The SNP rs7020813 was identified as a significant marker in the context of voltage-gated ion channels in cancer cell proliferation. This finding was part of a broader investigation into how altered functionalities of ion channels contribute to cancer, highlighting its relevance for potential therapeutic interventions.
title: High-frequency extracellular spiking in electrically-active cancer cells

finding: The association between rs7856187 and the family Lachnospiraceae was replicated in this study, indicating that this SNP may influence the presence or abundance of this microbial family within the gut microbiome.
title: A Comprehensive Assessment of Demographic, Environmental and Host Genetic Associations with Gut Microbiome Diversity in Healthy Individuals

finding: The SNP rs505922 was genome-wide significant for its connection to pancreatic cancer risk and confirmed the association with studies referencing the ABO locus.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel GP2 gene risk variants for pancreatic cancer in the Japanese population

finding: The intronic mutation in RABL6 at chr9:139731607:A:G was identified as a shared mutation among LUAD components of patients Pa31 and Pa35, as well as the SCLC components of those same patients. This finding underscored that while some mutations were shared between different histologic types from the same patients, overall, there was minimal overlap in mutations among the same histologic subtype across different patients. The context of this finding suggested that somatic mutations may not be the primary determinant of histology in these tumors.
title: The histologic phenotype of lung cancers may be driven by transcriptomic features rather than genomic characteristics

finding: This SNP was associated with the genetic dependency of IFNE. The specific association indicated a potential influence of gender variants present in different ancestral groups on the observed dependency, thus providing insights into how ancestry-related genetic differences may affect cancer treatment responses.
title: Germline variation contributes to false negatives in CRISPR-based experiments with varying burden across ancestries

finding: This SNP was linked to the genetic dependency of IFNA16. Similar to the previous finding, it highlighted the role of germline sequence variations tied to ancestry, which could influence the dependency of different genetic pathways linked to cancer.
title: Germline variation contributes to false negatives in CRISPR-based experiments with varying burden across ancestries
